repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Urban Environmental Sanitation
            Project, Village Infrastructure Project, and Second
            Community Water and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings were as follows: The Ghana Urban
            Environmental Sanitation Project had a satisfactory outcome,
            unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impact; the Village Infrastructure Project had a
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impact; and the Second Community
            Water and Sanitation Project had a highly satisfactory
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impact. The Bank's and
            Borrower's performances were satisfactory for all three
            projects. Three lessons were cited: 1) Decentralization
            requires an enabling institutional environment including: a
            long term commitment, a demand-driven approach including
            beneficiary contributions, clear institutional roles and
            guidance for all stakeholders, and a common implementation
            modality for all actors. 2) A major drive to build
            implementation capacity is essential including: major
            training for local governments, communities and private
            sector support services, emphasis on up-front capacity
            building before investment in infrastructure, strong central
            coordination including monitoring and evaluation, and
            integration of hygiene education alongside the investment
            program; and 3)  Sustainability needs to be a central focus
            including: priority on raising revenues for operations and
            maintenance, institutional adjustments to improve revenue
            collection, self-sustaining support services from the
            private sector, and follow-on training for the local
            governments and community organizations.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, with high institutional
            development impacts, and, satisfactory performances by the
            Bank and Borrower. The following are some lessons of
            experience: 1) The project utilized a large number of
            indicators, which were not always easy to measure, and did
            not promote efficiency in the management of the project.
            This reflects the trend that projects formulated more
            recently have a) fewer and b) easier-to-measure indicators.
            2) For community-driven development (CDD) projects,
            micro-project implementation depends on demand from
            communities. It is therefore difficult, and sometimes
            self-defeating, to predict the quantity of micro-projects
            that communities will request. The targets predicted are
            difficult to attain, or alternatively, can be substantially
            exceeded; this is mitigated by reviewing the indicators as
            projects progress, or, at Mid-term Review (MTR). On the
            other hand, the indicators chosen can be just qualitative in
            nature. 3) A large amount of capacity building and training
            is essential, even in an infrastructure project, to ensure
            optimal use of the infrastructure provided. Without
            institutional strengthening and capacity building, a project
            can fail in its original objectives (e.g. a dam built for
            irrigation can be used for drinking water only, making
            sub-optimal use of a large investment). This demonstrates
            that infrastructure development alone cannot lead to
            sustainability. The project demonstrated that approximately
            half of recipients are able to carry out their own planning,
            and subprojects as a result of the training provided by the
            project. However, the remaining half requires additional
            training, and, institutional strengthening and capacity
            building also led to communities taking control of their
            development. Other lessons address, and/or reinforce the
            importance of project ownership, of maintenance planning,
            and, of an integrated water, sanitation, and hygiene education.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Village Infrastructure Project will
            support government efforts to reduce poverty and increase
            the quality of life of the rural poor. The project has the
            following components: (1) Rural Water Infrastructure -
            comprising integrated development and water resources
            management, including catchment management and other water
            conservation practices; investments for the rational use of
            water for agriculture, livestock and human consumption
            including small dams, dugouts, boreholes, hand-dug wells,
            streamflow diversion and pumping to support small-scale
            irrigation in the dry season; and rainfall conservation and
            management for more effective use in rainfed crop
            production. (2) Rural Transport Infrastructure - selectively
            rehabilitating and improving degraded feeder roads;
            developing village trails and tracks linking farms to
            villages to permit the use of simple wheeled vehicles to
            reduce the need for women and children to head carry
            weights; and a pilot program to develop intermediate means
            for the rural poor to convey goods to market. (3) Rural
            Post-Harvest Infrastructure - developing on-farm and
            village-level drying facilities to reduce post-harvest
            losses; on-farm and community storage and other
            village-level market infrastructure for more efficient
            marketing; appropriate facilities for processing crops,
            livestock and fisheries products to increase their quality
            shelflife and market value; and income-generating activities
            targeted at the poorest. (4) Institutional Strengthening -
            capacity building within district assemblies to strengthen
            their planning and financial management of rural
            infrastructure; strengthening NGOs and other community-based
            organizations to provide more effective implementation
            support to communities and groups in developing sustainable
            rural infrastructure; and empowering beneficiary
            associations and groups to take direct responsibility for
            the sustainable operations and maintenance of rural infrastructure.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Village Infrastructure Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Village Infrastructure Project is
            aimed at reducing rural poverty.  This environmental
            assessment identifies potential environmental concerns and
            provides appropriate environmental guidelines for mitigation
            measures. In the water project subcomponents, contamination
            of surface and ground waters can be mitigated by conducting
            regular quality analyses.  Lined canals or pipes can be used
            to prevent disease vectors and seepage.  Ground water
            depletion can be reduced by ensuring that abstraction rates
            are consistent with natural aquifer recharge.  Reducing
            farming activities upstream can reduce sedimentation and
            discourage aquatic weed growth.  Salinisation may be
            controlled by leaching of salts through periodic flushing or
            soils.  In terms of rural transport infrastructure, road
            surface should be sealed with bitumen to avoid erosion.
            Frequent watering can reduce dust impacts.  Appropriate
            culverts and drifts can be used to eliminate flooding.  Axle
            loads of trucks should be regulated to avoid depressions and
            ponding.  As for the rural post-harvest infrastructure, some
            of the solid waste generated by processing equipment could
            be recycled.  Liquid waste should be analyzed to determined
            possible uses. The use of mud silos provides protection to
            dry crops and prevents bush fires.
